did.abstract: The Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies (JCPES) is a nonprofit American research and public policy institution, or think tank, founded in 1970 to aid black elected officials in creating effective policy and successfully serve their constituents. The collection includes subject files, writings, publications, photographs, audiovisual materials, and electronic records pertaining to JCPES events, programs, and projects especially of concern to African Americans in the late 20th century. Collection acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies Records (JCPES) are arranged into these series: Center Leadership and Administration; Center Offices; Center Institutes; and Electronic Records. Each of the series have been further arranged into subseries. The contents of each series or subseries are arranged hierarchically to reflect the Joint Center's original order.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Joint Center for Political Studies and Economic Studies (JCPES) is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization based in Washington, DC that creates policy and programs that improve the socioeconomic status and civic engagement of African Americans. The think tank was founded in 1970 as the Joint Center for Political Studies (JCPS) to aid black elected officials create effective policy and successfully serve their constituents. Founders included the social psychologist Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, and newspaper editor Louis E. Martin. The organization later became the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies (JCPES) 1990.

Joint Center scholars, researchers and analysts studies, conducted projects, and programmed forums and conferences covering increased political participation, job creation, workforce development, and health care strategies. Each of the events produced booklets, reports and booklets of use to government officials and the general public. These conversations included the Congressional Black Caucus, African American mayors, and state and local legislators. Interactions with presidential cabinet members, journalists, and foreign policy ambassadors represented the full spectrum of the American political system.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies Records were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2014.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of administrative records for the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, and includes correspondence, memoranda, budgets, funding reports, publications, policy research studies, conference materials, photographs, audiovisual media, and electronic records. Areas of study include healthcare, HIV/AIDS, minority business, television violence, young fathers, education, and minority community representation.

Among its many publications, JCPES published FOCUS magazine from 1972 to 2011, which covered national issues for an audience largely comprised of black elected officials (BEOs). The collection also includes oral histories of Joint Center founders and influencers, interview transcripts, an extensive history of JCPES, materials from the The Joint Center South Africa office which provided post-Apartheid political assistance activities, and original Southern Regional Council publications.

Other materials include interviews/oral histories with founders Louis Martin, educator Kenneth B. Clark who was the first African American president of the American Psychological Association; and McGeorge Bundy, who served as United States National Security Advisor to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson on foreign and defense policy from 1961 through 1966. Interviews and transcripts that add historical perspective to African American issues are conversations with Southern black mayors; African American architect and social activist Carl Anthony; and Ernest Green, one of the Little Rock Nine.

Conferences included forums, roundtables, and speeches from notable figures, elected officials, and congressional members including Maya Angelou, Joe Biden, Cory Booker, Edward Brooke, Ron Brown, Carol Moseley Braun, George H.W. Bush, Barbara Bush, Henry Cisneros, Shirley Chisholm, Bill Clinton, Hillary Clinton, Charles Diggs, John Hope Franklin, Jesse Jackson, Maynard Jackson, Valerie Jarrett, Barbara Jordan, Vernon Jordan, Jack Kemp, Coretta Scott King, John Lewis, Eleanor Holmes Norton, Barack Obama, Colin Powell, Charles Rangel, Ronald Reagan, Kasim Reed, Condoleezza Rice, Susan Rice, Donna Shalala, Rodney Slater, Doug Wilder, and Andrew Young. Joint Center historical notes compiled by Darlene Clark Hine are included, as well as Juan Williams' historical publication The Joint Center: Portrait of a Black Think Tank. The files and speeches of Joint Center past presidents Eddie N. Williams; Togo West, Jr.; Ralph Everett, Esq.; and past vice president Eleanor Farrar add insight to the Joint Center's mission of illuminating concerns and trends affecting 20th century African Americans to the legislative influencers most able to effect change.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to audiovisual materials is restricted. Contact the Rubenstein Library in advance to request access to or the production of a use copy.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this collection have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room. To request access, please contact a reference archivist before coming to use these records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included in the Center Leadership and Administrative series are administrative records in the form of progress and other reports, accounting files, correspondence, historic documents, minutes, by-laws, member biographies, photographs, and audiovisual media. They follow the Joint Center original arrangement, which may be chronological and/or alphabetical. The series is divided into two subseries: Board of Governors (BOG), and Office of the President (OOP). The BOG files relate to board activities, namely the annual dinner and meeting, that date back to the organization's founding in the late 1960s. The OOP files are divided into the offices of Eddie N. Williams, Togo D. West, and Ralph B. Everett, with each having their respective correspondence, speeches, and subject files. The Presidents' subject files were created by the OOP and include files for each of the three presidents represented in this collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to original electronic and audiovisual materials is restricted. Contact Research Services in advance to request the production of a use copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of original copies of annual dinner programs, correspondence, copyright and incorporation records, trademark certificates, member lists, biographies, conference planning documents, committee and board of governors meeting minutes, reports, research, and agendas. Photographs of major political figures, such as Coretta Scott King and Colin Powell, as well as pictures from Board of Governors meetings and other events can be found here. Audiovisual and digital materials are housed in this subseries. Materials follow the original arrangement, which may be chronological and/or alphabetical. The records for the Public Affairs, Research, Finance, and Development committees are included here.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Center Office series is divided into four subseries: Office of Development and Strategic Planning (ODSP) with materials consisting of prospective and major donor correspondence and reports that date from the early 1970s to 2011; Office of Governance and Economic Analysis (OGEA) which is comprised of the Joint Center reports from major research and policy initiatives sponsored by the Center; Office of Information Resources (OOR) consists of print materials published by the Joint Center, as well as reference sources used for research purposes; and Office of Communication and Marketing (OCM) which consists of published materials, organizational information, newsletters, magazines, employee profiles and resumes, documentary film proposals and transcripts, and electronic media.

did.unittitle: Office of Governance and Economic Analysis (OGEA)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of early writings, reports, and studies. The early writings relate to surveys and studies, funding initiatives, quarterly reports, and management training information. Reports and papers comprise the largest part of the series and pertain to various research and funding initiatives sponsored by the Joint Center. Topics include demographics, housing, employment, voting, leadership, education, and health. Various reports related to specific projects or entities, such as the National Policy Institute, can be found here.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Joint Center's Office of Information Resources/Library functioned as the organization's resource center and archive, and the subseries includes subject files comprised of Joint Center published and unpublished essays, conference proceedings, studies, and research on policy issues of concern to African American communities. This subseries also includes print materials that range from short pamphlets to books. Most of the materials were printed by the Joint Center. Other materials not printed by the Joint Center include reference books that were used to write reports and pamphlets. Print materials are arranged by topic and include health, voting, education, economics, policy, and Joint Center information. The Joint Center's main publications, Black Elected Officials: A National Roster, and FOCUS magazine, can be found here.The materials did not have a discernible original order and have been grouped by topic and arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 1993 the Joint Center's Office of International Affairs opened an office in Johannesburg, South Africa, to provide political assistance activities and legislative training to new post-Apartheid political parties. Research studies and projects focused on voter education and governance, youth HIV/AIDS programs in partnership with Schools Health and Population Education (SHAPE), and women's empowerment. Prior to the opening of the office, the Joint Center conducted economic, governance, and voting forums and summits. Materials are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 1981 and 1982, the Joint Center, Kenneth B. Clark, and John Hope Franklin assembled twenty-five scholars and policy leaders to discuss their publication, The Nineteen Eighties: Prologue and Prospect. The Committee for Policy on Racial Justice proceedings held in Tarrytown, New York yielded wide-ranging discussions about the effects of racism on African American families especially concerning the economy and education. The materials containing transcripts, correspondence, and reports, are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Partnering with funders, the Joint Center hosted institutes of specialized interest. The series includes administrative materials, working papers, final reports, electronic records, audiovisual media, and photographs from the National Policy Institute (NPI), the Civic Engagement and Governance Institute (CEGI), and the Institute for Responsible Fatherhood (IRF).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to original electronic and audiovisual materials is restricted. Contact Research Services in advance to request the production of a use copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The National Policy Institute (NPI) was held every four years at the beginning each presidential election year for groups representing black public officials from federal, state and local government organizations to present policy and work on issues of importance to African American communities. Later NPI became an independent program named the National Policy Alliance. This subseries includes programs, essays, special reports, fact sheets, financial reports, memorandums, correspondence, financial summaries, proposals, mailings, personnel rosters, steering committee documents, registration information, newsletters, budgets, projects, event planning materials, research, articles, surveys, agendas, lists of program participants, and photographs related to the event. The materials are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The mission of the Civic Engagement and Governance Institute (CEGI) was to understand how people of color perceive the world and to increase their participation in democratic institutions. To meet this goal, CEGI issued publications and sponsored events where topics included children's and adolescent health, HIV/AIDS, African Americans and climate change, Social Security, Medicaid, Latino reproductive health, and various community-based projects. Major funders included the Ford Foundation and the Annie E. Casey Foundation. This subseries is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: Roundtable and forums include itineraries, working papers, correspondence, and other documents related to the event. Each folder has been labeled and dated according to the date of the forum or meeting, although the dates of other supporting documents that accompany those materials may vary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The original computer disks acquired with the records of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies (JCPES) contain files of many types, chiefly software programs, memos, correspondence, events materials, analytical summaries of panels and meetings on a wide variety of social issues, and administrative materials such as budgets. These files have been migrated to a library server. The three video files all relate to the JCPES annual Gala Dinner event in 2013; for ease of access, .mp4 video files have been made available as use copies; access to original .mov files is availalable upon request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files are intended as access copies with content duplicating that of the original video files in .mov format. Original .mov video files are available upon request. The 2013 Annual Gala video chiefly focuses on the program speakers. Joe Biden, U.S. Vice President, gives a lengthy speech. Other speakers include JCPES Board Chair Cynthia Marshall, members of the Congressional Black Caucus, and Susan Rice, U.N. Ambassador.
